title: Application of a Modified Smart-seq2 Sample Preparation Protocol for Rare Cell Full-length Single-cell mRNA Sequencing to Mouse Oocytes
procedures: Part I: Oocyte isolationThis protocol should yield ~80-120 mature oocytes and ~200-300 immature oocytes per pooled sample (from four mice).Note: Prior to beginning this protocol, assemble the Hamilton pipette-based micropipette oocyte handling device as described in Xing (2010). Videos that detail the following procedures for oviduct removal and dissection can be found in the Journal of Visualized Experiments (Duselis and Vrana, 2007; Stein and Schindler, 2011). RLT buffer preparationClean pipettes and workspace thoroughly with RNase Away to avoid RNase contamination.Using PCR-rated filter tips, add 10 μl of β-mercaptoethanol to 1 ml of RLT buffer in a 1.5 ml Eppendorf tube and pipette to mix well.Note: 350 μl of the RLT buffer containing β-mercaptoethanol will be needed per RNA sample. Increase volumes proportionally to obtain the desired final volume. RLT buffer containing β-mercaptoethanol can be stored for up to 1 month at room temperature. Transfer 350 μl of the RLT buffer containing β-mercaptoethanol to each of two 1.5 ml Eppendorf tubes.Mice superovulation and tissue harvestingMature oocyte generation and oviduct isolationInject four 3-week-old female mice intraperitoneally with 5 IU of pregnant mare serum gonadotropin (PMSG) to induce oocyte growth.Forty-eight hours later, inject these same mice intraperitoneally with 5 IU of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) to induce oocyte ovulation.Euthanize the mice by cervical dislocation fourteen hours after hCG injection.Use sterilized fine forceps and fine scissors to remove the oviducts with attached uterine horn from each mouse (total of 8). Place tissues into a droplet of pre-warmed room temperature M2 media on an untreated 100 mm Petri dish.Transfer one oviduct-uterine horn sample at a time to a new 300 μl drop of pre-warmed M2 media on a new untreated 100 mm Petri dish.

Under a dissecting microscope, use two pairs of watchmaker’s forceps to tear the ampulla of the oviduct and release the cumulus-oocyte complexes into the surrounding media.Add 300 μl of 0.6 mg/ml hyaluronidase to the drop of media (final concentration of 0.3 mg/ml).Note: In order to optimize RNA quality, proceed directly to Procedure C prior to isolating immature oocytes from mice (Step B2). Immature oocyte generation and ovary isolationInject four 3-week-old female mice intraperitoneally with 5 IU of pregnant mare serum gonadotropin to induce superovulation.Euthanize the mice by cervical dislocation forty-four hours after PMSG injection.Use sterilized fine forceps and fine scissors to remove the ovaries from each mouse (total of 8). Place tissues into a droplet of pre-warmed room temperature M2 media on an untreated 100 mm Petri dish.Transfer one ovary at a time to a new 300 μl drop of pre-warmed M2 media supplemented with 10 μm milrinone on a new 100 mm Petri dish. Milrinone helps to ensure metaphase arrest of the oocytes (Stein and Schindler, 2011).Add 300 μl of 0.6 mg/ml hyaluronidase to the drop of media (final concentration of 0.3 mg/ml).Oocyte isolation Note: During the processing of immature oocytes, use M2 media supplemented with 10 μm milrinone.Under a dissecting microscope, puncture and gently dissociate the tissue with two 30-gauge needles to aid the release of oocytes into the surrounding media.Detach adherent cumulus cells from the oocytes by gently and repeatedly pipetting the cumulus-oocyte complexes using the micropipette.Once denuded of cumulus cells, wash oocytes three times by transferring the oocytes into new droplets of pre-warmed M2 media on the untreated 100 mm Petri dish using the micropipette.Count the total number of oocytes as they are drawn up into the micropipette.

Aspirate the minimal amount of media possible (less than 6 μl), as large volumes will dilute the RLT buffer.Transfer the counted immature or mature oocytes into the corresponding Eppendorf tube containing previously prepared RLT buffer.Vortex the tube at high speed for 45 s to homogenize the sample. Place tube on dry ice until it can be stored at -80 °C.Part II: Oocyte RNA library preparation RNA isolationThaw RLT samples on ice.Isolate RNA from the thawed samples using the RNeasy Micro Kit, according to the manufacturer’s instructions.Elute RNA in 14 μl of ultra-pure water and store at -80 °C until ready to proceed with library preparation.cDNA generationNote: The heated lid should be set to 105 °C for all thermal cycler programs. Preheat the PCR machine before running each program.Allow RNAClean XP beads to equilibrate to room temperature for 30 min before use in Step B4.Prepare Master Mix 1 and place on ice until ready to be used.Transfer 10 μl of each RNA sample to a corresponding well of a 96-well skirted PCR plate.Add 22 μl (2.2x) RNAClean XP beads to each sample and pipette gently to mix. Allow to incubate for 10 min at room temperature. The RNA is now bound to the beads.Place the 96-well plate containing beads and RNA on a 96-well magnet plate and incubate for 5 min. The magnetic beads will aggregate along the sidewalls of the wells.Use a multichannel pipette to carefully remove the supernatant without disturbing the beads.Wash the beads by gently pipetting 100 μl of 80% ethanol over the beads. Let stand for 1 min and then remove the supernatant without disturbing the beads.Repeat Step B7 for a total of two ethanol washes.Allow the beads to air dry on the magnet for 5 min.

Remove the 96-well plate from the magnet stand and resuspend each well of dried beads in 8 μl of Master Mix 1.Seal the plate with a Microseal B film, quick-spin the plate in a swinging bucket centrifuge to remove liquid from the sidewalls, and incubate the plate for 3 min at 72 °C. This step denatures the RNA.Immediately place the sealed 96-well plate on ice for 1 min. This step minimizes RNA secondary structure formation.Prepare Master Mix 2 and place on ice until ready to be used.Add 14 μl of Master Mix 2 to each well for a total volume of 22 μl and gently pipette to mix.Seal the plate with a Microseal B film and quick-spin the plate in a swinging bucket centrifuge to remove liquid from the sidewalls. Place the plate in a preheated thermal cycler with the heated lid set to 105 °C and run PCR Program 1 to perform reverse transcription of the RNA.PCR Program 1:50 °C for 90 min85 °C for 5 minPrepare Master Mix 3 and place on ice until ready to be used.Following reverse transcription, quick-spin the plate in a swinging bucket centrifuge to remove liquid from the sidewalls and remove the adhesive seal.Add 28 μl of Master Mix 3 to each well for a total volume of 50 μl and pipette gently to mix.Seal the plate with a Microseal B film and quick-spin the plate in a swinging bucket centrifuge to remove liquid from the sidewalls. Place the plate in a preheated thermal cycler with the heated lid set to 105 °C and run PCR Program 2 to amplify cDNA.

Note: Because of the difficulty of isolating oocytes in large numbers, coupled with the high cost of library preparation and sequencing, we chose a PCR amplification cycle number in Step B19 based upon Qubit results we obtained in Step B31 using equivalent input numbers of splenocytes. Ideally, the PCR amplification cycle number will be determined empirically using test samples of the same cell type and input cell number being sequenced. An ideal final concentration of cDNA is ~0.5 ng/μl, which permits further dilution of the cDNA sample to 0.2 ng/μl. PCR Program 2:98 °C for 3 minThen 12 cycles of:98 °C for 15 s 67 °C for 20 s72 °C for 6 minFollowed by:72 °C for 5 minAllow AMPure XP beads to equilibrate to room temperature for 30 min before use in Step B22.Quick-spin the plate in a swinging bucket centrifuge to remove liquid from the sidewalls and remove the adhesive seal.\Add 35 μl (0.7x) AMPure XP beads to each sample and pipette gently to mix. Allow to incubate for 5 min at room temperature. The cDNA is now bound to the beads.Place the 96-well plate on a 96-well magnet plate and incubate for 6 min.Use a multichannel pipette to carefully remove the supernatant without disturbing the beads.Wash the beads by gently pipetting 100 μl of 70% ethanol over the beads. Let stand for 1 min and then remove the supernatant without disturbing the beads.Repeat Step B25 for a total of two ethanol washes.Allow the beads to air dry on the magnet for 5 min.Remove the 96-well plate from the magnet stand and resuspend each well of dried beads in 40 μl of 1x TE Buffer to elute the cDNA from the beads for 5 min.Place the 96-well plate on a 96-well magnet plate and incubate for 5 min.

The magnetic beads will aggregate along the sidewalls of the wells. The cDNA is contained in the supernatant.Use a multichannel pipette to carefully transfer 36 μl of supernatant from each well into a new well of the same 96-well plate (one well per pooled sample).Quantify the cDNA concentration of each sample using a Qubit dsDNA HS kit, according to the manufacturer’s instructions.The cDNA quality can be analyzed using a 2100 Bioanalyzer with the high sensitivity DNA kit, according to the manufacturer’s instructions. The average size of the PCR-amplified cDNA library should be 1.5-2 kb, as described alongside representative Bioanalyzer traces (Picelli et al., 2014).Normalize the cDNA concentration of each well to 0.2 ng/μl using 1x TE Buffer.Proceed to RNA-seq library generation using Illumina’s Nextera XT Kit with 1 ng of cDNA as input.
